title: There appears to be no way to print a message after installing a package
body:
The singluarity package ([a WIP here](https://github.com/spack/spack/pull/11094#issuecomment-484274715)) would like to print out a helpful message to the user after the installation (suggesting that they chown some files to `root` and make one of them `setuid`).

There doesn't seem to be any way to do this.  I've tried overriding various installation steps and/or wrapping them, to no avail.  I eventually figured out that the output was going to the log file, not the terminal.

The cleanest solution that I've come up with is to add a *hook*, e.g. `lib/spack/spack/hooks/post_install_message.py` that checks whether a package implements a method named `post_install_message` and calls the method if so.

```python
 # Copyright 2013-2019 Lawrence Livermore National Security, LLC and other
 # Spack Project Developers. See the top-level COPYRIGHT file for details.
 #
 # SPDX-License-Identifier: (Apache-2.0 OR MIT)

 import llnl.util.tty as tty

 def post_install(spec):
     """Give package a chance to send a post installation message."""
     pkg = spec.package
     if (hasattr(pkg, "post_install_message") and
         callable(getattr(pkg, "post_install_message"))):
         tty.debug("Calling post_install_message()")
         pkg.post_install_message(spec, spec.prefix)
```

Packages could then use it to warn the user, e.g.:

```python
def post_install_message(self, spec, prefix):
     tty.warn("Danger Will Robinson!")
```

**Have I missed an obvious way to do this?**

**If not, is something like the above an interesting/acceptable solution?**
